body: I am thinking this could be fairly simple to start.  Extend org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.InputFormat and use the Accismus snapshot iterator.  In the long run, need to ensure the Accismus GC does not delete the snapshot thats being read.
Hey Keith. Would you mind if I took this one on?

Sure, I am not working on it.

something is done for this now, but its not perfect.  The worker checks if the notification exist when it sees an exception.  If the notification does not exist, it assume a collision occurred.
have some scripts now.  Still need a simple script to start workers across a cluster.
This is a task underneath #2

I wanted to do this initially, but there was a problem.

If two workers have different versions of the class (or a map reduce job loading data has a different version of a class), then this could cause problems.   In addition to different classes, it possible that an observer could be missing.  For example if a M/R job is loading data, there is no need for it to have all of the Observers on its class path. 

One way to resolve this is the load the Observers at initialization time, ask the Observers which columns they observe, and then store that info in zookeeper.  This way there is a consistent view across the cluster of what columns to notify on.  Initialization should log at INFO what its persisting.  Updating this info would be an administrative option.  With this strategy, the only configuration needed for initialization is a list of observers.
Accismus oracles and workers can now be started across a cluster using YARN.  See #11 for more info.

Need insight on collisions.  If an Observer is frequently colliding, users will need to know.

May also want to track info about load transactions not run by Workers.
#13 allows efficient discovery of failed transactions.  This issue is about making recovery more efficient after detecting failure.
Should probably cache the transactors status from zookeeper.
Especially when running multiple Oracle's on a single node for testing, this will be useful. It will also be useful for users to fine-tune their system to meet their needs.

I think we should eventually have a ticket to refactor the Configuration object into something a tad more maintainable. Not sure what that would look like yet, but I can quickly see it becoming hard to maintain when we start externalizing more of the configurations
I have bumped into this problem a few times when running multiple oracles.

Just realized I hadn't updated upstream in awhile.

Yeah I had to resolve some conflicts, but git made it easy. There was one rename it did not detect for some reason, but that file only had one a few changes and I just redid them.

Some use cases :
1. An Observer throws an unexpected exception.  What could help a developer debug this?  It seems like one thing that would help alot would be the data that the transaction read.  If the data could be set aside for a developer to replay, this would be very useful.
2.  An Observer is frequently colliding with other observers.   In this case knowing what data was read would be useful.  

Maybe workers could optionally write the Observer class, exception, and data read by the transaction to a file in HDFS.

Design for BitTrie stress test:
- Generate files containing random 32bit or 64bit integers
- Using integers to create a trie using bit sequences of 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, or 32 bits for nodes
- Starting at leaf nodes, notifications are passed up the trie to count the number of leaf nodes
- Leaf nodes are only created once to dedup integers.
- Count at root node should equal the number unique integers used in test
- Node bit sequence can be modified to create conflicts (larger # of bits / nodes = more conflicts)
- MapReduce job needs to be created to calculate counts seperately from Accismus.
+1 for Avalance. I tend to like the weather names (Storm, Avalanche) because they impose something larger than ourselves; something that that's capable of extreme power and scale.
duplicates #15
I still need to implement th watcher for the leader changing and have the server deny to serve a timestamp if it is not the leader. I shouldn't have created yhe pull request so soon.

Spent a few minutes with a thesaurus to see what I could find. 

Blitz - fast and with great power
Flux - the rate of transfer of fluid, particles, or energy across a given surface. Also: a continuous flowing body
Metasis - a rapid transition, as from one subject to another. Also: a change in position or orbit of an elementary particle.
Niagara -  anything taken as resembling Niagara Falls in force and relentlessness; avalanche
Landslide - the downward falling or sliding of a mass of soil, detritus, or rock on or from a steep slope
Spate - a sudden, almost overwhelming, outpouring

It would be useful to try and reproduce these too:
- Oracle loses its connection to zookeeper for a brief period and reconnects (leader selector should requeue).
- Client loses its connection to Zookeeper while leader changed
- All oracles go down. (Client should immediately connect when the first oracle comes back up).

Looking at it the patch, I did start to think of the things that could go wrong, which made me realize a really good test suite is needed #37.  I decided to apply it because it was an improvement over what was there.

Pull request #40 should help a tad with some of these cases as the OracleClient will listen for events from Zookeeper for changes to the children of the ZNode being used to compete for leadership and pro-actively adjust its connection to the oracle server.
AFAICT, port 9913 is where we're exposing the thrift service for the Oracle. This isn't a web server.

This can still cause a dos attack

> Client connected to an oracle process thats paused

What exactly do you mean by paused?

A process thats temporarily unresponsive because its swapped out Java GC
has stopped all threads.

Fluo is unique for sure. I like this as well.

I was able to reproduce this exception with the following stack trace:

2014-06-24 23:26:38,174 [server.THsHaServer] ERROR: run() exiting due to uncaught error
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
    at java.nio.HeapByteBuffer.<init>(HeapByteBuffer.java:57)
    at java.nio.ByteBuffer.allocate(ByteBuffer.java:331)
    at org.apache.thrift.server.AbstractNonblockingServer$FrameBuffer.read(AbstractNonblockingServer.java:338)
    at org.apache.thrift.server.AbstractNonblockingServer$AbstractSelectThread.handleRead(AbstractNonblockingServer.java:202)
    at org.apache.thrift.server.TNonblockingServer$SelectAcceptThread.select(TNonblockingServer.java:198)
    at org.apache.thrift.server.TNonblockingServer$SelectAcceptThread.run(TNonblockingServer.java:154)

This seems to be a common thrift issue when the incorrect protocol is used. In this case, we're using a TCompactProtocol.

Mike, have you ever used/heard of Travis CI? It seems to have good integration with Github. It also supplies the hosting and runs the builds on the developers forks as well.

https://travis-ci.org/
Travis CI looks cool and its free for open source. It's definitely worth checking out.

there are two different max message size settings in thrift you can set. One just limits the overall message size, the other limits the size of any individual frame. The former prevents attacks from giant legitimate requests, the latter prevents garbage from bringing it down. This is something I recently fixed in Accumulo, but I really don't feel like digging up the ticket number right now. I'm sure you can find it. HBase also is just fixing / in the process of fixing this.
Looks like ACCUMULO-2360. Thanks John!
Hey Keith. I think this pull request is ready for review.

A random though I had when looking at the code was that an Oracle should not start accepting connections, if it can still get timestamps from the old Oracle instance this helps preserve sanity in many cases, but not in the partition case
Should we start renaming packages, docs, and repos soon?

> an Oracle should not start accepting connections, if it can still get timestamps from the old Oracle instance

OracleServer should not start accepting connections if an OracleClient can still get timestamps from the old OracleServer instance?
I was thinking when an Oracle server becomes leader, it could try connecting the previous oracle server (if any) and not start accepting connections if it can connect.

while looking into this I noticed the properties added for yarn are not really consistent w/ the current model.   The yarn properties are in the connection props files.  Also the yarn props do not have yarn in the property name.

The branch this pull request was based on got stale and could no longer merge cleanly.  I ran the following commands and got it back in shape.

```
git checkout master
git pull
git checkout Accismus-16
git rebase master
# had to follow instructions and resolve conflicts
git push -f
```

This pull request picked up the changes from the forced push, but it seems to have no record of the stale version of the branch that I can see.
What is the purpose of the "-1" in the version?  (Why not 1.0.0-alpha?)  I am not arguing that it should be changed.  Just wondering why..

I was googling looking for conventions w/ alpha and I kept seeing alpha-1.  I thought about it seemed good if for some reason a second alpha needed to be tagged.  If there would be more than 9, it seems like alpha-01 should be used
That makes sense.

I changed README.md to point to Fluo.git and the Travis CI to point to Fluo.svg. This pull request should probably be synchronized with the renaming of the repo. I'm thinking we should probably still have keith-turner/Accismus provide a link to keith-turner/Fluo so that users don't get confused.

I added the proper synchronization to lock all writes/access to currentLeader and client. Mind if I create a different ticket / pull request for having the OracleServer check the last leader when it is elected?

I don't think we can use org.fluo.  That domain seems to be registered.   I just bought fluo.io domain just in case, so maybe we can use that or just make the package name fluo

Renaming should be a cinch

https://help.github.com/articles/renaming-a-repository

I am going to take over reviewing this pull request from keith.  Can you squash your commits into one on the branch?  See http://gitready.com/advanced/2009/02/10/squashing-commits-with-rebase.html for help.  When you have have squashed the commit into one on your branch, you can push the changed commit history to your origin using "git push origin <BRANCH> --force".  Github will update the pull request.  

In general, we are trying to have one commit correspond to each issue as it makes it easier to review.

Mike,

Thanks for taking this over while Keith is gone!  I definitely don't mind following more atomic commits with respect to tickets. I need to clean this branch up a bit- it became a bit of a behemoth. The only reason I haven't closed it is because of the comment history.

Thanks for putting all of the code into one commit.  I am starting to review the code today but I am new to the Oracle code this might take some time.  However, this is a good chance for me to learn it.  I'll put comments in the code as I go and will let you know when I am finished.

Thanks again Mike. I think we should post in our development process docs
that we are expecting atomic commits so future devs don't get confused.
Well tend to do this on Accumulo as well and we have clearly documented it.

Was thinking about this a little. Seems like it might make sense to allow the user to configure the host _as well as_ the port for the thrift socket. That way they can bind to a specific interface. By default maybe use InetAddress.getLocalHost().getHostName()?

We are using YARN right now to start Accismus oracles and workers on a cluster.  Therefore, it's easier for processes to discover their hostnames rather than set the hostname through configuration.  If there is a use case for setting hostnames through configuration, we can always add it later.  

I did a little research on best way to get hostname from Java.  It looks like `Runtime.getRuntime().exec("hostname")` should be used to get hostname.  See this [stackoverflow question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7348711/recommended-way-to-get-hostname-in-java) for more info.

Ah, yeah I've seen that post before- there can certainly be discrepancies that can arise between `hostname` and getHostName(). Hadoop Operations also demonstrates these discrepancies.

My concern with the hostname is only when a user wants to force the use of a different interface, I was thinking more about this weekend- users can just configure the host to the interface they need in the OS layer.

We created a nice utility for random ports (that aren't already open) in Accumulo:

https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=accumulo.git;a=blob;f=server/base/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/server/util/PortUtils.java;h=f710b0f1385e69539abe61476e630d969f4799b3;hb=HEAD

I'm assuming this entails adding Spark as a dependency of Accismus?

It would only be a dependency of the stress module.  It can be excluded
from the Accismus distribution.  However, it looks like Spark needs to be
installed on a node to submit an application to YARN.

That's where my only concern is. In order for a collaborator or contributor to run the stress tests, they are going to have to have a system available with both Yarn and Spark configured. I'm only thinking about this assuming that at some point this will be a release requirement. Do we have resources available for this project that we can all get access to?

> However, it looks like Spark needs to be
> installed on a node to submit an application to YARN.

I think I may be reading this differently than how you intended it. I'm reading this as _In order to submit an application to YARN, you need to have Spark installed on a node_. I don't think that's how you intended it, though.
It would be nice if we could get the outstanding pull request (#71) reviewed and merged before this gets merged in.

You need to have Spark installed on a single node to submit Spark
applications to YARN.  I added this story as a reminder to come back to
it.  More research needs to be done before deciding to make the switch but
I will make sure that any Spark set up is easy and well documented in the
README of stress module before moving to Spark.  I think making the
ingest/verification code for the stress test easier to understand will be
worth any extra set up.
